11:19 am
BE

Bottom Line: Tonight’s FDA approval of lifitegrast for treatment
of dry eye came earlier than expected and SHPG scored several
victories in its package insert (label) that will position the drug to
become the company’s next blockbuster drug. The lifitegrast approval
came ahead of a 7/22 PDUFA date. SHPG plans to launch lifitegrast in
3Q16 under the trade name Xiidra. SHPG has not yet announced Xiidra
pricing but we’d expect the drug to be priced on par with AGN’s (OP)
Restasis at ~$300/script. Two important features of the Xiidra package
insert will provide positive differentiation against AGN’s Restasis: (1)
onset of action – the clinical trial section highlights that Xiidra showed an
improvement relative to placebo on the symptom endpoint in 2/4 studies
as early as two weeks compared to Restasis which ophthalmology
specialists say has a 6-8 week onset; (2) breadth of label claims – Xiidra
is indicated for treatment of both signs and symptoms of dry eye disease,
whereas Restasis was approved only on a demonstrated improvement
in objective signs of dry eye. We believe the Xiidra approval was widely
expected based on three positive pivotal studies, an FDA priority review
designation, SHPG included lifitegrast approval in its 2016 guidance
and sell-side consensus estimates of $1.1B by 2021E. We view the
market for dry eye as poised for significant expansion, with ~9 million
moderate to severe patient candidates versus ~1m pts currently treated
with branded Restasis. Based on our ophthalmologist KOL checks, there
are a significant number of eligible pts who have either failed to adhere
to Restasis due to tolerability and/or slow onset and there is pent up
demand for a new topical anti-inflammatory as the last drug approved in
the space was 2003. We expect the Xiidra approval to expand the dry
eye category from ~$1.4B current to $3B. We currently forecast lifitegrast
sales of ~$900m and $1.3B by 2021 and 2026 respectively. Xiidra’s
composition of matter patent expires May 2026E and method of use
patent expires 2029E. We reiterate our OP rating.

BE

(@Soundbuy: that advice applies equally before a beer or two.)

BE

And Deutsche Bank .........

11:20 am
BE

We continue to expect its fast-onset, good tolerability and strong
efficacy to give it significant advantages over incumbent Restasis (Allergan)
and allow Shire to generate sales of $1.1bn by 2020E (6% of Group) and
$1.6bn by 2024E. Given continued investor nervousness over the approval and
labeling, we expect the news to act as a meaningful catalyst to share price
performance. Xiidra makes up 7% of our NPV and 21% of our 2016-2020E
sales growth forecasts.

BE

We expect Shire to launch Xiidra during 3Q16 via its newly built
ophthalmology sales force. Although pricing has not been disclosed, we
expect it to seek to capture the drug’s benefits via a premium to Restasis
(current WAC $426/month) and see upside to our current revenue/patient
assumptions ($1600 net revenue/patient based on 6 months therapy). The
launch will essentially de-risk Shire’s plans to build a leading ophthalmology
franchise, with additional pipeline drugs, including FST-100 (infectious
conjunctivitis), representing upside to our assumptions.

BE

An estimated 16 million adults in the U.S. are diagnosed with dry eye disease,
of which we estimate greater than 900k are currently treated with Restasis. Although we
expect Allergan to vigorously defend its position, we expect Xiidra to ultimately
emerge as market leader. Our previous physician survey suggests potential for
rapid uptake given likely use in: (1) patients dissatisfied with Restasis; (2) a
large population of patients previously failing Restasis; and (3) in combination
with Restasis. In addition, our survey suggests Xiidra should emerge as a
preferred first prescription agent for moderate-to-severe patients and suggests
potential for a significant expansion in the market for prescription dry eye
disease therapies, with patients with moderate-to-severe disease treated with
a prescription agent more than doubling over five years.

11:21 am
BE

And Cowen, since they never miss a change to say that Shire's going to the moon.

PM

So there is a prescription alternative

PM

(Sorry - go on - -Cowen)

11:21 am
BE

As for our previous survey of 19 thought-leading ophthalmologists in the U.S., the key
takeaways were: (1) 95% think Lifitegrast/Xiidra's clinical data indicates “good" or
"impressive” results; (2) the vast majority (90%+) believed Xiidra would be approved
with the data that has been accumulated to date (and as we saw yesterday evening,
they were indeed correct); (3) roughly 75% indicated Xiidra should be used for all
types of dry-eye sufferers, and not limited to any one dry eye subset; (4) 65%+ believe
the product will be either the same size as Restasis (estimated to be $1.5B+ in 2017),
while 20%+ believe Xiidra could ultimately be 2x the size of Restasis (making it a
potential $3.0B product using Restasis as the baseline), which means that 85%+
believe Xiidra could ultimately become a roughly $1.5-3.0B product; and finally (5),
50%+ believe that roughly 40-50% of their dry eye patients should be on Xiidra three
years post launch, and in total, roughly 90% of respondents believe that at least
20-50%+ of their patients should be on Xiidra three years post launch. We believe
all of these metrics appear exceedingly positive for the impending Xiidra launch and
future potential market opportunity, which is now de-risked.

BE

As an aside, while we believe Xiidra could eventually become the category leader due
to its differentiated efficacy and tolerability profile, we believe the launch should have
minimal impact on the sales of Allergan's Restasis. In fact, there have been several
instances where we have observed multiple drugs in an underpenetrated category
where the overall market continues to expand and the leading product's growth
might pause briefly – but then resumes – while the new entrants garner significant
revenue (Pfizer's Xalatan for glaucoma during the launch of Allergan's Lumigan,
Pfizer's Viagra during the introduction of Lilly's Cialis, just to cite two examples). This
is even more true in categories that currently are underpenetrated and have a lack
of meaningful advertising despite a significant available population. We would note
that the predominant sufferers for dry eye are menopausal women, which is a large
and growing category that our clinician consultants believe would respond favorably
to increased promotional effort and direct-to-consumer marketing, which we believe
Shire will deploy once its formulary coverage is established and broadened. This
type of promotional effort should afford ample room to grow the category, not at the
expense of the current market leader. Other examples of categories and products that
momentarily paused but then exhibited continued growth include statins, triptans,
SSRIs, beta blockers, and glaucoma. The bottom-line is that we believe the dry eye
market has ample room for both participants.

PM

Restasis -- CYCLOSPORINE eye drops are used to increase tear production in patients who have dry eyes due to eye inflammation.

11:24 am
BE

Cowen, meanwhile, I've got to page 7 of the Cowen note where it's drifted off into fantasy reverse-M&A.

BE

A Divestiture Of The Neurology/Vyvanse Franchise Would Place SHPG/BXLT
In A Position To Rapidly Pursue Additional Orphan, Longer-Duration Assets

BE

we believe that the Baxalta transaction could simply be the
initial step in a multi-step process that would eventually allow Shire to pursue
various strategic options but from a more stable earnings base. Although admittedly
the Neurology division – and specifically Vyvanse – has been a key component
of the recent Shire growth story, we believe that with the anticipated approval of
Lifitegrast, growth of Natpara and Gattex, likely eventual introduction of DX-2930,
and with growth still available in the base product portfolio (via Elaprase, Replagal,
Firazyr, Cinryze and Lialda), it is possible that divesting this shorter duration division
would still render a proforma entity that has favorable – and durable – growth
prospects well into the next decade. And we would assume that if management
pursued this divestiture, that it would have a very clear view of the manner in which
– and how quickly – it would or could deploy the capital to further strengthen the
durable growth thesis. We readily admit, what we have just discussed above appears
complicated, exhausting, and some may argue a reach, or potentially too challenging
for management to accomplish. Nonetheless, given the rapid changing nature of
this industry, as well as the aggressive nature of the Shire management team/board,
we believe that this analysis could provide some insight into what strategic options
they may be reviewing. And following our analysis, we believe that if this pathway
was pursued it could yield values at significantly higher levels than here if the capital
was properly deployed. As we indicated above, our analysis of the Neurology division
yields a valuation close to $11-13B. Any value near $10.0B would make it NPV neutral.

11:25 am
BE

As for the potential buyers of this division (which would include Vyvanse, second
generation SHP465, Intuniv and Adderall XR), we believe there are various potential
suitors that could make sense. Note, for perspective, Vyvanse currently is annualizing
at roughly $2.0B, and has experienced Y/Y growth of +18% in 2014 and +19% in 2015
as increased penetration into the adult market, and the new binge eating disorder
indication, have driven utilization. Importantly, we believe the product will grow at
+16% for full year 2016 (recall, in Q1 it grew at 22% Y/Y), and should easily reach
$3.0B+ at the time of generic introductions in 2023/2024. And we would note that this
level of growth has been experienced despite Shire's lack of a meaningful primary
care effort, which restricts the ability to fully exploit the adult/binge eating indications.
We believe an even broader primary clinician call effort – potentially provided by
a large pharmaceutical buyer – could drive even greater penetration. Additionally,
Shire has had favorable results for SHP465, which could provide for an even longer-
acting stimulant, which could also potentially benefit the still growing adult segment
of Adderall and Adderall XR users. This product could theoretically recapture many
of the Adderall/Adderall XR adult patients, and provide a re-branded product with
intellectual property protection through May 2029. Given this still interesting and
growing portfolio, the question is which pharmaceutical companies would want
such a division, could leverage the products due to having a primary care and CNS/
psychiatric commercial call effort – and also have a strategic or financial need. We
would also note that many of the potential purchasers would also likely be able to
use some of their currently trapped ex-U.S. cash given the portfolio carries Shire's
foreign domicile.

BE

Goes on to list J&J, Pfizer, Otsuka and Novartis as the potential buyers.

BE

That's page 7. It's a 24 page note.

BE

Here's Barclays.

BE

A straight forward and reassuring set of 3Q numbers from ASOS today with a sales beat across all its geographies and positive outlook from management. 3Q sales were up 30% a material beat to Instinctif consensus of +23% and our estimate of +24%. Management raised official FY guidance to the top end of a +20-25% sales growth range which will likely be well received by investors today. The gross margin was down 180bps due to timing of sales into 3Q and continued price investment, but it was actually 20bps better than feared. We would expect the gross margin to improve into 4Q. Management kept the FY gross margin guidance of up to -50bps intact. What is particularly optimistic for the future is the fact that active customers grew by 24% in 3Q, an acceleration vs. +17% in 2Q. Active customers can be a good leading indicator for future growth. We continue to find ASOS a very appealing growth proposition with very positive momentum and a beneficiary of a weak sterling. Management’s priority remains strong growth over any margin progression at this stage, a message that they have kept clear in several occasions recently. We reiterate ASOS as our Top Pick.

BE

This compares to Zalando on 37.4x, 19.4x and 1.17x respectively and YNAP on
39.1x, 14.3x and 1.31x.

BE

Price Target 2,200p, based on a simple average of our lease-adjusted residual income and DCF valuations (rounded for presentational purposes). The valuations assume a long term EBIT margin of 6%, a cost of equity of 8.8% and a WACC of 8.8% (calculated on the basis of a risk-free rate of 5.0%, an equity risk premium of 3.8%, a beta of 1.0 and a long term cost of debt of 6.5%) and a terminal growth rate of 3%. The key upside risks include international growth acceleration as the introduction of zonal pricing and investment overseas increases ASOS' competitiveness, continued benefit from FX and bid speculation.

11:37 am
PM

here is a scientific paradox which revolves around a cat in a box that may be dead or alive. How do you know unless you open the box and look? How can you tell that the action of opening the box doesn't kill the cat, or bring it back to life? In short, does observing whether the cat is dead or alive create the outcome?

PM

In this respect we believe that PMO is in the same position with its debt. If it looks, it will breach its covenants, but if it doesn't ask the question, it can say that it doesn't breach. We get the impression in this instance that Management know that their debt cat in the box is dead, but until they open it up and look, they can say that it isn't; QED: no breach.

PM

This doesn't change the fact, however, that outside of the Management team, the way in which this has been articulated, strongly suggests, with a high degree of confidence, that the covenants have been breached, otherwise, why would the Management team leave the Company's future in limbo for so long while they renegotiate the covenants?

11:38 am
PM

We would expect the share price to stage a rally in the short term as the Company’s owners express relief, but this does not escape the fact that the outlook for the Company is less in the hands of management, and more in the hands of its creditors. This could be terminal for the Durant reign, which let’s not forget signalled that the Company was ex-growth by initiating a share buyback programme in a falling oil price environment to generate shareholder value.

PM

In the longer term however we are more confident that the Company will survive as there is a significant number of highly regarded members of the Management team that can step in seamlessly if the need arises, to help navigate the Company’s future, potentially through what is becoming an increasingly difficult time.

PM

So, to be more specific, Spangel don't like Tony Durrant,

11:39 am
PM

Once the outlook for the Company stabilises, or at least the path that it will follow becomes more certain, we believe that attention will start to turn towards the decisions that have been made, when and how. As with all companies in these positions, we believe that the Management team need to start to articulate what the future plan will be, and what portfolio action they will take, because against this backdrop, we can’t see its Falklands ambitions surviving.

BE

Well ..... okay, I can see the argument.

BE

Premier is a bit like Thomas Cook, or the housebuilders in 2009, or whatever. It had a near-death experience from which it has recovered as much by stabilising markets and good fortune as much as self help.

11:39 am
BE

BE

BE

With regards to whether that extension is already in the price ............. dunno. Davy think it is.

11:42 am
BE

..... with a boring note I won't quote, as it just gives the bullet points. Here's Jefferies instead.

BE

The trade off - deleverage oil price versus NAV oil price. Current net debt of $2.6bn
is slightly reduced from last update ($2.68bn) and should peak at greater than $2.8bn in 3Q16. We see US$42/b as the oil price required for free cashflow in 2017 (and at strip oil price of $54/b in 2017 generates PMO $184m of FCF next year) but our price target (75p/sh) requires $72/b flat oil price to be reached in NAV terms. Trading at $11.9/boe on 2P reserves (ex-Sea lion) the company is below precedent UK North Sea M&A metrics for a producer of this size ($13/ boe for Dana in July 2010) and is very geared to comparison with such precedent (110p/sh at $13/boe 2P reserves) which arguably is a possible share price scenario for PMO (rather than an M&A scenario) if good operations can continue.

BE

Fundamental debt refinancing should be a 3Q expectation rather than a risk, in our view, and with costs coming down for Catcher, and E.On assets performing well the company is well set to start de-levering the balance sheet from 2017 onwards.

11:44 am
BE

So the buyers stay buyers, the sellers stay sellers. Make your own decisions I guess.

Vodafone Group PLC (VOD:LSE): Last: 226.30, down 3.7 (-1.61%), High: 228.55, Low: 224.45, Volume: 22.29m
BE

11:51 am
BE

BE

11:52 am
BE

Anyway. Here's Citi.

BE

We downgrade Vodafone to Neutral from Buy as the stock looks to us to be up with events after a period of decent performance. Following the positive May results, and with the Netherlands JV with Liberty Global likely to take until the end of the year to close, we do not expect a significant positive catalyst for another two quarters or so. Vodafone has so far ridden out the general political risk in Europe, outperforming UK stable-mate BT by 27% YTD (only partly due to £/€ -13% YTD), but the October constitutional referendum in Italy could challenge this, among other election risks. In Italy we also see potential for greater competitive pressure with Iliad positioning to enter the market via the 3/Wind deal remedies. Together these suggest a more cautious stance despite the attractions of the increasingly well-covered yield, better revenue mix and growing market share in fixed broadband.

BE

We update our forecasts and transfer to Euros from sterling consistent with the company's new reporting from here on. We update FX and make some downward changes to underlying estimates, lowering growth in the UK (near term) and Italy (longer term) and in the smaller European assets. Like for like forecast EBITDA falls c.1% to €15.5bn, €15.3bn and €15.9bn in FY17e, 18e & 19e. Our SOP-based target price falls 3% in Euros, on lower multiples for Italy, Spain and the UK, but in sterling rises to 245p from 240p due to translation from the £/€.

11:52 am
BE

In fiscal 1Q17 we expect group organic service revenue growth of +1.9%, slightly up on the +1.8% underlying figure for 4Q16 due to mainly mechanical improvements in Spain and India that overcome pressure in the UK and from the impact of mobile roaming price regulation of around c.35bp at group level.

BE

We still regard a combination with Liberty Global as having strong industrial logic (see How to Make It Work) but believe completing and proving the Netherlands JV probably come first. A parent deal though may be more viable now LBTY's market cap is 34% of Vodafone's, vs 54% in March 2015.

Hotel Chocolat has delivered a strong update leading to a modest upgrade to forecasts. The statement is reassuring in that the new store pipeline is strong, the capital projects are on track, on time and within budget and momentum from FY16E has continued strongly into FY17E. We have a high degree of confidence in forecasts and as we discuss below we feel Hotel Chocolat possess the many attributes of a high quality business. We retain BUY and reiterate our TP of 230p, +33% upside.

BE

Summary of update and forecast upgrade

Revenues of £92.6m are now expected to be achieved in FY16 (Liberum forecast: £91.6m), an increase of 12% compared to the prior year. The Group ended FY16 with 85 stores – in line with Liberum forecasts. The most recent store opened in Sheffield on 9 May, and has been trading in line with expectations. The Group has secured four new stores which are expected to open before Christmas 2016.

Forecast changes: We have amended our forecasts to reflect a better outturn in 2016E than we had anticipated. Sales are now expected to have grown 12.1% YoY, some 1.1% faster than we had forecast at the time of the IPO. Our PBT forecast rises by 1.6% to £6.9m realising growth of 141% YoY on a pro-forma basis.

Liberum view: The second half of the year has seen strong sales with both January and Easter being the two key trading periods. This better out-turn is a reflection that the group’s ranging and marketing capabilities have all improved and the group’s digital channels having grown 20% during the year. We have prudently left our outer year forecasts unchanged and will revisit as appropriate at the prelims.

BE

Revenue growth will be driven by new store openings, growth from digital channels, corporate gifting and the roll-out of the Shop + Café concept. Efficiency gains and benefits from increased capacity, automation and capital projects across the business should drive EBITDA margin expansion from 9.8% in 2015 to 14.7% by 2019E. Liberum forecasts are prudently set but there are multiple reasons to believe levers for upgrades exist:

Our margins assume that only 33% of the possible cumulative efficiency gains (from the capital projects) flow through our forecasts,
There is little benefit from the launch of the new web-interface in FY17E and beyond,
We only assume 5 new shops p.a. During the last downturn Hotel Chocolat expanded its estate 120% (or by 48 shops) during the 2007-2012 downturn. It is our belief that Brexit may yet again provide opportunities that could lead to additional stores than we had initially anticipated.

12:01 pm
BE

It's easier to add 48 shops when you have no shops, and the mothers of Kensington etc are as yet unbothered by your little packets of chocolate. Less so when you're having to open in places like Sheffield to find growth.

BE

Investment thesis

We believe that Hotel Chocolat possesses multiple attributes that support a high level of confidence in forecasts. 1) It is a highly disruptive business and has proven defensive attributes irrespective of the economic backdrop, 2) the customer base is largely UK, low ticket products and a large portion of its customers are ABC demographic and 3) it has a high growth online business and a very "sticky" core membership in its Tasting Club.

The group has just started its capital investment programme to increase capacity, automation and improve efficiencies in its manufacturing plant which will drive significant margin enhancement over the next few years. With strong cash generation and low debt, Hotel Chocolat has to be one of the best placed companies under our coverage.

Our view: Outperform; 4,500p PT
Our addressable market analysis suggests that ASOS is still in the very early stages of growth and is underpenetrated both in terms of market share and active
customers. We think ASOS should be well placed to benefit from both the structural growth in the global online apparel market as well as from the ongoing
improvements being made to its customer propositions - we forecast a 5yr revenue CAGR (FY15-20E) of 20%. In particular, we think ASOS’s growth potential in
the US is underappreciated. We are also optimistic about the impact of local buying on the gross margin and see scope for EBIT margin expansion post FY16.
At 1.8x CY17E EV/sales, we think current valuation fails to discount the longer-term revenue growth opportunities.
